Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research fellowship awarded to Matthew Badger is "Geometry of Measures and Analysis on Rough Domains." The host institution for the fellowship is Stony Brook University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Raanan Schul.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geometric measure theory is a field of mathematics pioneered by Besicovitch in the 1920s and 1930s, which grew out of a need to describe non-smooth phenomenon such as the formation of singularities in soap bubble clusters.  The term "measure" refers to an abstract generalization of length, area, or volume, which assigns a size value to every mathematical set. Traditional outlets for geometric measure theory such as the calculus of variations and geometric analysis have expanded in recent decades to include harmonic analysis and partial differential equations.

Under this award, the PI's research focused on fundamental problems in geometric measure theory and applications of geometric measure theory to free boundary problems associated with elliptic partial differential equations. The PI's work with the PI's postdoctoral sponsor, R. Schul, expanded our understanding of rectifiable measures, one of the fundamental objects in geometric measure theory, extending results originally due to Besicovitch. Another milestone in the history of geometric measure theory occured in the 1960s with Reifenberg's study of regularity properties of a class of sets (now called Reifenberg flat sets) that admit uniform local approximations by Euclidean planes. The PI and S. Lewis initiated the study of general sets of Reifenberg type, which allow approximations by sets with singularities that appear in geometric minimization problems and in free boundary problems for elliptic partial differential equations. This framework enabled the PI, M. Engelstein, and T. Toro to make a detailed study of the singular set in a two-phase problem for harmonic measure with only weak initial regularity assumptions on the boundary of the domain. In another project with J. Azzam and T. Toro, the PI explored applications of geometric measure theory to quasiconformal geometry, establishing new conditions on the geometric distortion of a quasiconformal map that ensure the associated "quasiplane" is rectifiable. Finally, the PI also carried out research on the "modulus of measures", a notion of "richness" of a family of measures defined by Fuglede in the 1950s and based on ideas developed by Beurling and Ahlfors in the 1940s. The PI solved a long-standing open problem of characterizing "extremal metrics" for the modulus of a family of measures in an abstract measure space.

The research supported by this award resulted in 5 published journal articles, including articles in the high level journals Advances in Mathematics and Mathematische Annalen. The research results were broadly disseminated in numerous conferences and research seminars at universities across the United States and also in Finland. Activities by the PI with broader impacts during the tenure of this award included co-organizing an American Mathematical Society special session on "Complex Analysis, Probability, and Metric Geometry" with J. Gill and J. Lind at University of Tennessee in Knoxville, TN in March 2014 and teaching a mini-course on an "Introduction to the Geometry of Sets and Measures" for graduate students and postdocs at a conference at Temple University in Philadelphia, PA in April 2014.
